Award.AwardTitle: GOALI Collaborative Proposal: 3D RF Microsystems using Direct Digital Manufacturing Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objectives Research is proposed that will advance design and fabrication techniques relating to direct digital manufacturing (DDM), or additive manufacturing of three-dimensional, reconfigurable microwave microsystems. DDM is a layer-by-layer fabrication approach which can combine structural, functional and sacrificial materials in a single build of arbitrary-shaped structures. The work will investigate devices that include new transmission line geometries, deployable 3-D antennas and tunable cavity filters. Mechanical reconfiguration based on DDM-produced shape-shifting surfaces will also be studied.

Intellectual Merit DDM has enabled significant technical innovation in a wide range of fields, from bio-medical devices to fuel cells, but utilization in RF/microwave applications is in its infancy. To date, high frequency applications have consisted primarily of the deposition of conductors on conformal surfaces to create antennas and simple interconnects. This project will explore the integration of innovative electronic and mechanical design techniques that are compatible with a low cost, common manufacturing platform to produce 3D microwave systems.

Broader Impacts Reversing the loss of high-tech manufacturing jobs is of vital importance to the Nation?s economic security, and thus the outcomes of this project could have significant societal impact. DDM is also a green technology that eliminates material waste associated with subtractive manufacturing and so has a positive impact on environmental sustainability. The outcomes of the research will be integrated into undergraduate education through joint REU activities between the partnering institutions, and also into the graduate curricula at each school. Graduate student exchanges are planned along with summer internships at Sciperio to enhance professional development.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to investigate the use of emerging digital additive manufacturing (AM) technologies for producing microwave components. Additive manufacturing has received significant attention across a broad spectrum of industries for reasons that include extremely low prototyping costs, low material waste, and the ability to produce objects that are difficult or impossible to produce with conventional manufacturing processes. The AM technologies that were studied include those for producing plastic parts as well as a micro-dispensing technique that is used to deposit different types of pastes, including conductive pastes. A common characteristic of these techniques is that the material – whether plastic or paste – is deposited in a layer-by-layer fashion to build up three-dimensional geometries as defined by a computer-aided-design (CAD) file. By combining plastic deposition with conductive paste deposition, functional electronic devices can be 3D-printed. The microwave components of interest were primarily antennas, transmission lines and other devices used in wireless systems (filters, couplers, amplifiers, etc.).  The research focused on three aspects: 1) investigation of new materials, 2) development of new material testing techniques, and 3) studies of the AM-produced microwave components.  The area of material development is particularly important, as the types of plastic materials that are currently available and compatible with the selected AM techniques is very limited. In order to enable more advanced, miniaturized and high performance microwave components an expanded library of materials is needed. Significant advances were made during the project with the demonstration of composite materials that combine plastic with ceramic particles, to the point where the range of material properties available for the AM techniques is now approaching that which is available for traditional printed circuit board manufacturing. The area of material testing was critical to this project since a complete understanding of the materials that were being deposited required knowledge of how the properties of those materials varied with location within a sample. In this work a method called near-field scanning microwave microscopy was advanced, and the improvements were especially important for studying the characteristics of the micro-dispensed conductive paste and using this knowledge to significantly improve its conductivity to the point where the paste behaves nearly was well as a bulk metal (e.g. silver).  In terms of applications, a number of novel components were designed and demonstrated for operating frequencies ranging from the wireless range (around 2.45 GHz) to the millimeter-wave range (above 100 GHz). Rigorous analysis of these components provided a deep understanding of how the material properties, the resolution of the printing techniques and the morphology of the 3D-printed structures (and in particular the surfaces) impact high frequency performance.  This understanding will provide a valuable foundation for future studies on the use of AM-techniques for fabricating microwave components. The broader impacts of the project include the training of twelve graduate students, providing research experience for eight undergraduate students, and an outreach project with a Florida high school where students designed and fabricated their own 3D-printed objects with included an antenna and radio frequency identification (RFID) tag.

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2016
Modified by: Thomas M Weller
